name: Barry Moore
bio: Barry Moore is the U.S. Representative for Alabama’s 1st congressional district. He previously represented the 2nd district and served in the Alabama House. A veteran and small business owner, Moore is known for his conservative positions and membership in the House Freedom Caucus.
education: Auburn University (BS in Agricultural Science)
endorsements: House Freedom Fund, National Rifle Association, Alabama Farmers Federation
platform: Border security, fiscal responsibility, veterans’ support, and agricultural development.

platformFollowThrough.Border Security: Supported legislation to increase funding for border enforcement and oppose sanctuary policies.
platformFollowThrough.Fiscal Responsibility: Voted against omnibus spending bills and supported balanced budget amendments.
platformFollowThrough.Veterans’ Support: Advocated for expanded mental health services and faster claims processing for veterans.
platformFollowThrough.Agricultural Development: Introduced bills to reduce regulatory burdens on farmers and expand rural broadband.

proposals: Secure the border, cut wasteful spending, support veterans, and empower rural communities.

billsPassed.title: H.R. 6162 — Postal Facility Naming Act (2024)

name: Shomari Figures
bio: Shomari Figures is the U.S. Representative for Alabama’s 2nd congressional district. A Mobile native, he previously served in the U.S. Department of Justice and as a senior advisor in the Biden administration. He is the son of longtime Alabama lawmakers Michael and Vivian Figures.
education: University of Alabama (BA, 2006; JD, 2010)
endorsements: Congressional Black Caucus PAC
platform: Voting rights protection, rural healthcare access, infrastructure investment, and economic development.

platformFollowThrough.Voting Rights Protection: Publicly supported legislation to restore key provisions of the Voting Rights Act.
platformFollowThrough.Rural Healthcare Access: Introduced the Rural Hospital Stabilization Act to support underserved medical facilities.
platformFollowThrough.Infrastructure Investment: Serves on Transportation & Infrastructure Committee, advocating for broadband and highway modernization.
platformFollowThrough.Economic Development: Supports USDA rural business programs and small business loan expansion.

proposals: Protect voting rights, stabilize rural hospitals, expand broadband, and grow small businesses.

name: Mike Rogers
bio: Mike Rogers is the U.S. Representative for Alabama’s 3rd congressional district and has served in Congress since 2003. A native of Calhoun County, he previously served in the Alabama House of Representatives. Rogers is known for his leadership on national defense and currently chairs the House Armed Services Committee.
education: Jacksonville State University (BA, MPA); Birmingham School of Law (JD)
endorsements: National Rifle Association, Alabama Farmers Federation, Club for Growth
platform: National defense, border security, veterans’ services, and conservative fiscal policy.

platformFollowThrough.National Defense: Chairs the House Armed Services Committee and led passage of the FY2026 National Defense Authorization Act.
platformFollowThrough.Border Security: Supported legislation to increase border wall funding and restrict asylum loopholes.
platformFollowThrough.Veterans’ Services: Advocated for expanded VA access and mental health support for rural veterans.
platformFollowThrough.Fiscal Policy: Voted for tax cuts and opposed omnibus spending increases.

proposals: Strengthen national defense, secure the border, support veterans, and reduce federal spending.

billsPassed.title: H.R.3838 — FY2026 National Defense Authorization Act

name: Robert Aderholt
bio: Robert Aderholt is the U.S. Representative for Alabama’s 4th congressional district, serving since 1997. A former judge and legal advisor to Governor Fob James, Aderholt is known for his conservative positions on fiscal policy, agriculture, and religious freedom. He is one of the longest-serving members of the Alabama delegation.
education: University of Alabama (BA, 1982); Cumberland School of Law (JD, 1987)
endorsements: National Right to Life, Alabama Farmers Federation, Family Research Council Action
platform: Pro-life legislation, rural development, religious liberty, and conservative budgeting.

platformFollowThrough.Pro-Life Legislation: Consistently supported bills restricting federal funding for abortion and expanding conscience protections.
platformFollowThrough.Rural Development: Advocated for USDA rural broadband and water infrastructure grants.
platformFollowThrough.Religious Liberty: Cosponsored legislation to protect religious expression in schools and public spaces.
platformFollowThrough.Conservative Budgeting: Opposed omnibus spending bills and supported balanced budget amendments.

proposals: Defend life, expand rural infrastructure, protect religious freedom, and reduce federal spending.

name: Dale Strong
bio: Dale Strong is the U.S. Representative for Alabama’s 5th congressional district. A former emergency responder and chairman of the Madison County Commission, Strong is known for his focus on national security, border protection, and conservative values. He was elected in 2022 to succeed Rep. Mo Brooks.
education: Athens State University (BS, Business Administration)

platformFollowThrough.National Defense: Serves on Armed Services Committee and supported FY2025 NDAA.
platformFollowThrough.Conservative Budgeting: Opposed omnibus spending bills and supported rescinding unused COVID relief funds.

name: Terri Sewell

platformFollowThrough.Economic Justice: Championed tax credits for low-income families and small business development in underserved areas.

name: Nick Begich III

Nick Begich Sr. and focuses on energy, infrastructure, and Arctic innovation.

name: David Schweikert

name: Eli Crane

A former Kentucky Agriculture Commissioner and state legislator, Comer currently chairs the House Oversight and Accountability Committee. He is known for his work on government transparency, agriculture, and conservative oversight of federal agencies.
education: Western Kentucky University (BS)
endorsements: National Right to Life, Kentucky Farm Bureau, Club for Growth
platform: Government accountability, agricultural policy, fiscal conservatism, and border security.

platformFollowThrough.Agricultural Policy: Advocated for hemp legalization and expanded crop insurance for Kentucky farmers.
platformFollowThrough.Fiscal Conservatism: Supported spending caps and opposed debt ceiling increases without budget reforms.
platformFollowThrough.Border Security: Backed legislation to increase enforcement and restrict asylum loopholes.

proposals: Hold Washington accountable, support Kentucky farmers, cut wasteful spending, and secure the border.

In May 2025, she was indicted on three federal charges related to an altercation with ICE agents during a protest at Delaney Hall. Her legal team argues the charges are unconstitutional and politically motivated.

She is a senior member of the House Armed Services and Intelligence Committees and previously chaired the House Republican Conference. Stefanik represents the North Country and is a close ally of Donald Trump. In 2025, she released a book on antisemitism in higher education and is widely expected to run for governor of New York in 2026. A recent Manhattan Institute poll showed her narrowly leading Governor Kathy Hochul in a hypothetical matchup.

Mannion represents Central New York and the Mohawk Valley, including Syracuse and Utica. He is known for his advocacy on education, labor rights, and clean energy. In 2025, he launched a district-wide workforce development initiative and secured funding for regional green manufacturing hubs.

She is known for her advocacy on election integrity, law enforcement, and farm policy. In 2025, she pushed for expanded crop insurance and opposed federal voting reforms she deemed unconstitutional.

name: Eleanor Holmes Norton
bio: Eleanor Holmes Norton is the non-voting U.S. Delegate for the District of Columbia, serving since 1991. She is a civil rights attorney, former chair of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, and a leading advocate for D.C. statehood. Norton represents Washington, D.C. residents in Congress, where she can vote in committees but not on final passage of legislation. In October 2025, she was scammed out of $4,362 by individuals posing as HVAC workers, prompting a police report that noted signs of early-stage dementia. Her office disputed the report’s characterization and confirmed she is running for re-election in 2026.

In her first two terms, she had 13 bills signed into law, including legislation supporting sexual assault nurse examiners and clean energy innovation. In 2025, she continues to champion equality, justice, and progress.

He is known for his fiscal conservatism and emphasis on government accountability.

A former White House and FDIC official, Arrington chairs the House Budget Committee and serves on the Agriculture Committee. In 2025, he introduced legislation to cap federal spending growth and expand crop insurance protections. He is known for his fiscal conservatism, support for rural communities, and advocacy for energy independence.
education: Texas Tech University (BA, MPA)
endorsements: Texas Farm Bureau, National Taxpayers Union, American Energy Alliance
platform: Fiscal discipline, agriculture, rural development, and energy independence.

platformFollowThrough.Rural Development: Advocates for broadband expansion and healthcare access in rural areas.
platformFollowThrough.Energy Independence: Backs domestic oil and gas production and regulatory reform.

proposals: Balance the budget, protect farmers, invest in rural Texas, and unleash American energy.

name: Joaquin Castro
bio: Joaquin Castro is the U.S. Representative for Texas’s 20th congressional district, serving since 2013. He represents much of San Antonio and Bexar County. A former Texas state representative and attorney, Castro serves on the House Foreign Affairs and Intelligence Committees. In 2025, he was named the most effective Democratic lawmaker in the House by the Center for Effective Lawmaking. He introduced over 30 bills, including legislation to expand bilingual education, protect immigrant rights, and strengthen U.S. diplomacy. He is known for his leadership on Latino representation, global engagement, and civil rights.

endorsements: League of United Latin American Citizens (LULAC), EMILY’s List, National Education Association

name: Chip Roy
bio: Chip Roy is the U.S. Representative for Texas’s 21st congressional district, serving since 2019. He represents parts of Austin, San Antonio, and the Hill Country. A former chief of staff to Sen. Ted Cruz and federal prosecutor, Roy serves on the House Judiciary and Rules Committees. In 2025, he introduced legislation to defund sanctuary cities and cap federal spending. Known for his confrontational style and strict constitutionalism, Roy is a leading voice in the House Freedom Caucus.

endorsements: House Freedom Caucus, National Rifle Association, Club for Growth

name: Troy Nehls
bio: Troy Nehls is the U.S. Representative for Texas’s 22nd congressional district, serving since 2021. He represents parts of Fort Bend, Brazoria, and Harris counties. A former sheriff of Fort Bend County and Army veteran, Nehls serves on the House Transportation and Infrastructure and Veterans’ Affairs Committees. In 2025, he introduced legislation to expand mental health services for veterans and co-sponsored bills to increase border enforcement and support law enforcement agencies. He is known for his tough-on-crime stance and advocacy for military families.

bio: Tony Gonzales is the U.S. Representative for Texas’s 23rd congressional district, serving since 2021. He represents a sprawling district that includes over 800 miles of the U.S.-Mexico border. A retired Navy cryptologist and cybersecurity expert, Gonzales serves on the House Appropriations and Armed Services Committees. In 2025, he introduced legislation to bolster border technology and support military families affected by government shutdowns. He is known for his bipartisan outreach and focus on national security and infrastructure.

A former mayor of Irving and HUD regional administrator, Van Duyne serves on the House Ways and Means and Transportation and Infrastructure Committees. In 2025, she introduced legislation to reform the Small Business Administration and restrict commercial driving licenses for undocumented immigrants. She is known for her tough stance on immigration, support for entrepreneurs, and advocacy for transportation safety.

A former Texas Secretary of State and auto dealership owner, Williams chairs the House Small Business Committee and serves on the Financial Services Committee. In 2025, he introduced legislation to simplify the tax code for small businesses and expand access to capital. He is known for his pro-business stance, fiscal conservatism, and support for deregulation.

A former investment banker and founder of the conservative news site DC Enquirer, Gill serves on the House Judiciary and Homeland Security Committees. In 2025, he introduced legislation to expedite the removal of criminal aliens and restrict foreign ownership of U.S. farmland. He is known for his alignment with former President Trump and his focus on immigration, national sovereignty, and cultural conservatism.

He represents a border district that includes Laredo, Rio Grande City, and parts of San Antonio. A former Texas Secretary of State and state legislator, Cuellar serves on the House Appropriations Committee. In 2025, he continued to advocate for border modernization and trade infrastructure while facing an active House Ethics investigation stemming from a 2024 indictment for alleged bribery involving foreign entities. Despite the legal scrutiny, Cuellar remains a prominent voice on U.S.-Mexico relations and border policy.

Crockett serves on the House Oversight and Judiciary Committees and is known for her sharp questioning and advocacy on civil rights, voting access, and economic justice. In 2025, she introduced legislation to expand voting protections and police accountability. Crockett is reportedly considering a 2026 U.S. Senate run amid redistricting changes that may shift her district boundaries.

In 2025, he secured funding for Fort Cavazos upgrades and introduced legislation to streamline VA benefits processing. He is known for his advocacy for military families, conservative budgeting, and judicial reform.

In 2025, she introduced bipartisan legislation to reform prior authorization in healthcare and expand mental health access. She is the first openly LGBTQ+ member of Congress from the South and is known for her advocacy on healthcare, education, and equality.

name: Mark Pocan
bio: Mark Pocan is the U.S. Representative for Wisconsin’s 2nd congressional district, serving since 2013. He represents Madison and surrounding areas. Pocan is a former Chair of the Congressional Progressive Caucus and serves on the House Appropriations Committee. In 2025, he co-led a letter opposing executive orders that target protected speech and supported legislation to reimburse federal workers for childcare costs during the October shutdown. He is known for his advocacy on labor rights, LGBTQ+ equality, and government transparency.

name: Derrick Van Orden
bio: Derrick Van Orden is the U.S. Representative for Wisconsin’s 3rd congressional district, serving since 2023. A retired Navy SEAL and former actor, he represents a district that includes La Crosse, Eau Claire, and western Wisconsin. Van Orden serves on the House Agriculture and Veterans’ Affairs Committees. In 2025, he introduced legislation to expand rural veterans’ access to mental health services and supported increased border security funding. He is known for his outspoken style and focus on conservative priorities, including energy independence and law enforcement support.

name: Gwen Moore
bio: Gwen Moore is the U.S. Representative for Wisconsin’s 4th congressional district, serving since 2005. She represents Milwaukee and surrounding areas. Moore serves on the House Ways and Means Committee and is a senior member of the Congressional Black Caucus. In 2025, she hosted a maternal health roundtable and condemned FEMA’s denial of disaster aid following historic flooding in Milwaukee. She is known for her advocacy on economic justice, maternal health, and civil rights.

Grothman serves on the House Education and the Workforce Committee and the Oversight Committee. In 2025, he praised President Trump’s peace deal between Israel and Hamas and continued his advocacy for family-centered tax reforms and education policy. name: Tom Tiffany
bio: Tom Tiffany is the outgoing U.S. Representative for Wisconsin’s 7th congressional district, having served since 2020. He previously served in the Wisconsin State Senate and Assembly. His district includes much of northern and western Wisconsin. Tiffany is known for his strong conservative stance on energy, immigration, and federal land use. In September 2025, he announced his candidacy for governor of Wisconsin, triggering a competitive Republican primary to replace him in Congress. He serves on the House Natural Resources and Judiciary Committees.

name: Tony Wied
bio: Tony Wied is the U.S. Representative for Wisconsin’s 8th congressional district, serving since November 2024 after winning a special election to succeed Rep. Mike Gallagher. A business owner and former college football player, Wied represents northeastern Wisconsin, including Green Bay and the Fox Valley. He serves on the House Judiciary and Homeland Security Committees. In 2025, he introduced the FIRE Act to protect gun rights and the SAFE Cities Act to restrict federal funding to jurisdictions deemed 'anarchist' by the DOJ. He also co-sponsored a bipartisan bill to ensure statewide access to Green Bay Packers broadcasts.

name: Harriet Hageman
bio: Harriet Hageman is the U.S. Representative for Wyoming’s At-large congressional district, serving since 2023. A trial attorney and Wyoming native, she previously ran for governor and served on the Republican National Committee. Hageman represents the entire state and serves on the House Judiciary and Natural Resources Committees. In 2025, she introduced legislation to dismantle federal land management agencies and expand state control over energy development. She is known for her focus on land rights, energy independence, and opposition to federal regulatory overreach.
